attributes.title: TOO FANSI
attributes.description: Investigation of ANS congruency effects with and without feedback

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: The role feedback plays in reducing influence of non-numeric cues on numerosity judgments

other.value:
We will fit a Bayesian, multilevel regression in Stan, modeling changes in sensitivity and bias as a function of cumulative area (i.e., treated as a continuous variable of dot size), feedback condition, and their interaction. Essentially a variant of a generalized linear model, the likelihood function will model binary choice (Dot/Digit display as 'more') as a Bernoulli trial. The probability of choosing the side with dots will be modeled as a cumulative normal with an extra parameter to estimate lapse rates, as in classical signal detection theory. The slope and intercept of the regression model index sensitivity and bias respectively, with coefficients for cumulative area (i.e., dot size), feedback, and their interaction that index changes in sensitivity and bias. Parameter estimates will be deemed credibly different from 0 if their 95% credible interval excludes 0. If an important effect is deemed not credible, we will calculate Bayes Factors via the Savage-Dickey ratio method for the effects to assess how strong the evidence for 0 effect is.

When possible, priors will be set in advance from posterior distributions from preexisting experiments. For the effects of interest (now unknown), we will calculate priors based on a plausible range of expected effect sizes based on past literature. This will be a maximally informative prior, as the size of Bayes factors will depend heavily on the prior.

Note: Stan uses a Hamiltonian Monte Carlo sampler; in cases of small amounts of data within each subcondition (e.g., due to data loss or counterbalancing), it is possible (though unlikely with this design) that the lack of information may cause divergent transitions in the chain. If so, these will be resolved by using non-centered parameterizations of the parameters causing the issue (Betancourt & Girolami, 2013; https://arxiv.org/pdf/1312.0906.pdf).

sample.value: We will run 52 participants (26 per condition), consistent with a power analysis done for a previous pre-registered study that explored the influence of non-numeric cues on numeric judgments.

analyses.value:
Our primary analysis is an ANOVA to test the interaction of the cumulative area of the dots (e.g., dot size, treated as a continuous covariate), condition (i.e., whether participants received feedback), and ratio on % time dots were selected. For the GLM intercept, the same ANOVA will be run without ratio.

If there are any interactions, we will follow-up with Tukey-corrected pairwise comparisons of estimated marginal means.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded if they (1) did not fully complete the task (i.e., finished less than 100% of the trials) or (2) had chance performance (determined through a binomial test).

Participants will additionally be excluded for self-reporting a learning or developmental disorder.

Any participants that are excluded for the aforementioned reasons will be replaced until the target sample is met.

dependent.value: The dependent variable will be the percentage of time participants selected the side with dots as more numerous (as opposed to side with the digit) across ratios. We will calculate this both as the raw % of time, but also as the intercept of a GLM model across ratios. We expect these two measures to give us the same result.

conditions.value:
Main Between-Subjects:
- Feedback condition (i.e., participants will receive accurate positive and negative feedback based on their accuracy across trails)
- No Feedback condition (i.e., participants will progress through the trials, without being informed of their accuracy) 

Within-Subjects:
- Dot size "congruency" (i.e., the cumulative area that the dots take up on the side of the screen which they are shown) 
- Dot-to-Number Ratio: 2.0 (easy; e.g., "10" vs. 20 dots) 1.5, 1.2, 1.07, 0.93, 0.83, 0.67, 0.5 (e.g., "20" vs 10 dots).

hypothesis.value: At what level(s) of processing is feedback effective in reducing the influence of non-numeric cues in numerosity judgments?

study_type_other.value: We filled out but failed to submit the pre-registration before collecting data. We are submitting this pre-registration before any formal data analysis is completed, however.

q3.value: This study will look at the relationships between self-concept clarity and media related body dissatisfaction. Self-concept clarity is referred to as having a clear, certain understanding of who you are. Media related body dissatisfaction refers to the extent to which people experience body dissatisfaction specifically following media exposure. Previous research has exposed a relationship between these two constructs, so the purpose of this study will be to discover this connection experimentally.

q4.value: The primary hypothesis is that reducing self-concept clarity in women prior to exposure to body-positive media will increase opportunity for internalization of the media message, resulting in an increased post-exposure state body-appreciation. The secondary hypothesis is that enhancing self-concept clarity in women prior to exposure to thin-ideal media will prevent internalization of the media message resulting in an unaffected post-exposure state body-appreciation. We are predicting an effect size of f = .25.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Amazon’s Mechanical Turk will only prompt those who identify on their site as female to participate in the study. Following informed consent, the female participants will begin by filling out some demographic information. This will include age, weight and height. Demographic information will be filled out prior to the study so that an assessment can be made on attrition rates. Participants will then be randomly assigned to experience either low or high self-concept clarity manipulations. Low self-concept clarity manipulation will prompt, “Describe two aspects of your personality or two self-beliefs that conflict with each other. You have to describe what they are, how you feel the two conflict with each other, and the confusion that the conflict brings to you” (Jiang, Chen, & Sedikides, 2019). High self-concept clarity manipulation will prompt, “Describe two aspects of your personality or two self-beliefs that are coherent with each other. You have to describe what they are, how you feel the two are coherent with each other, and the clarity that the coherence brings to you” (Jiang et al., 2019). These manipulations have been used previously to successfully place participants into both low and high self-concept clarity mindsets. Following the manipulations, participants will again be randomly assigned into one of three exposure experiences. One exposure will be “thin-ideal” images, another will be “body-positive” images, and finally an exposure of “body-neutral” control images. After the exposure experience, participants will fill out the State Body Appreciation Questionnaire (Homan, 2016). All manipulations, exposures, and evaluations will be completed through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, and data will be analyzed using Qualtrics and SPSS. A two-way ANOVA will be used to measure the impact of manipulation, exposures, and the interaction between manipulation and exposure.

Controls: 
Two controls will be measured in this experiment; mood, and upward and downward physical appearance comparisons. In order to control for mood, we will assess mood at the end of the study using the Modified Differential Emotions Scale. Mood will be analyzed as a potential covariate. 

Some previous, correlational research on self-concept clarity, media internalization, and body-appreciation suggest that appearance comparisons may play a role in the relationships examined in this study (Vartanian, Froreich, & Smyth, 2016). In order to test for this potential mediation, upward and downward physical appearance comparisons will be measured at the end of the experiment using the Upward and Downward Physical Appearance Comparison Questionnaire (O’Brien et al., 2009). We will use a mediation measurement to test whether or not appearance comparisons mediate the relationship between exposure and body-appreciation.

q9.value: There will be two levels of randomization in our study. The first level will randomize participants to manipulation groups, and the second will be to randomize participants to exposure groups. Both will be simple randomization, so each group will have relatively the same number of participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: All of our data will be analyzed in Qualtrics and collected through Amazon's MTurk. Our inclusion criteria is 18+ year old females. The population sample will come from MTurk. Our recruitment descriptions will be as follows, "Participate in a study on identity and images from the media. Participating in this study involves writing short answers about yourself and your personality, looking at pictures, and answering some questions about your feelings. This study involves viewing images related to body-image, that some people may find upsetting. The study will take about 7 minutes. For your participation, you will earn $0.70. The purpose of this study is to understand how personal identity relates to viewing media images.” As stated in the recruitment description, participants will be paid $0.70 for participation. Subjects will be eligible for selection as long as they are female participants signed up for Amazon MTurk.

q13.value: Our maximum sample size will be 423 participants.

q14.value: Research by Cohen, Fardouly, Newton-John. & Slater (2019) suggested an effect size of f=.17 for the effect of body positive images on body appreciation. Using G*Power, we specified and ANOVA with six groups (2x3), which determined that a sample size of n = 423 would be sufficient to achieve power = .95.

q15.value: I will request 423 responses from MTurk. Any deviation for the pre-determined sample size will be due to the idiosyncrasies of MTurk (i.e. more or fewer participants completing the study than submitting HITs.)

question.value:
The high and low self-concept clarity manipulations come from previous research that has proven successful in manipulating these two mindsets. JLow self-concept clarity manipulation will prompt, “Describe two aspects of your personality or two self-beliefs that conflict with each other. You have to describe what they are, how you feel the two conflict with each other, and the confusion that the conflict brings to you” (Jiang, Chen, & Sedikides, 2019). High self-concept clarity manipulation will prompt, “Describe two aspects of your personality or two self-beliefs that are coherent with each other. You have to describe what they are, how you feel the two are coherent with each other, and the clarity that the coherence brings to you” (Jiang et al., 2019). 

The definitions for exposure groups come from previous research on thin-ideal and body-positive media exposure. All media participants will experience will come from public Instagram accounts. Each exposure group will contain 30 total images, 20 real life images and 10 motivational or inspirational quotes, in order to depict a realistic Instagram feed. The criteria for thin-ideal content comes from previous Instagram exposure research in which they define thin-ideal media as, “Images of attractive women with thin and toned bodies. Instagram posts of idealized women tend to depict thin women either posing in bikinis, form-fitting or revealing fashion or in fitness attire” (Cohen, Fardouly, Newton-John, & Slater, 2019, p. 1551). Following this definition, media images will be selected from public Instagram accounts such as; @victoriassecret, @kendaljenner, and @fitspo. Criteria for body-positive media content also comes from Cohen et. al., who suggest, “‘body positive’ refers to rejecting unrealistic body ideals and encouraging women to accept and love their bodies at any shape and size. Body positive Instagram posts tend to depict women proudly posting their unique bodies and quotes about body acceptance” (2019, p. 1550). In regard to this definition, media images will be selected from Instagram accounts such as; @aerie, @savagexfenty, and @bodypositivememes. For our neutral control media, we will use images of nature from accounts such as; @natgeo, @showyourtravelpics, and @nature.

Body appreciation will be measured using the State Body Appreciation Scale. This state body-appreciation survey uses a Likert Scale from 1-5 (1 = Never, 2 = Seldom, 3 = Sometimes, 4 = Often, 5 = Always) to assess how closely a participant relates to certain phrases regarding state body-appreciation. Phrases cover body-respect, body qualities, attention to body needs, etc. (Homan, 2016). 

In order to control for upward and downward appearance comparisons, the Upward and Downward Physical Appearance Comparison Scale will be utilized. This survey uses a Likert Scale from 1-5 (1 = Never, 2 = Seldom, 3 = Sometimes, 4 = Often, 5 = Always) to assess how closely participants relate to statements regarding both upward and downward appearance comparisons. 

Mood will be measured at the end of the experiment using the Modified Differential Emotions Scale. This will ask participants to think back to how they felt during the study, and indicate to what extent they felt certain emotions, on a scale of 0-4 (0=Not at all, 1=Hardly, 2=A little, 3=Somewhat, 4=A great deal). Positive and negative emotions will be averaged separately.

I will calculate two separate indixesof emotion by averaging responses to positive items on the differential emotions scale, and averaging responses to negative items on the differential emotions scale.

I will calculate an index for body appreciation by averaging all items on the scale.

I will calculate an index for upward and downward social comparisons by averaging all items, keeping upward and downward social comparison averages separate.

We will use a 2(self-concept clarity: high vs. low) x 3(media type: thin-ideal, body positive, or control) ANOVA, predicting body appreciation.

To test whether emotions mediate the interactive effect of self-concept clarity and media exposure, we will use a Process Model 7 with self-concept clarity and media type as the X and W variables, positive and negative emotions as mediators, and body appreciation as the dependent variable.

To test whether social comparisons  mediate the interactive effect of self-concept clarity and media exposure, we will use a Process Model 7 with self-concept clarity and media type as the X and W variables, upward and downward social comparisons as mediators, and body appreciation as the dependent variable.

q20.value: We do not plan on preforming any transformations.

q21.value: We will be using a two-tailed test for our analyses, considering significance at p<.05.

q22.value: We will exclude data points from our analyses if participant fails the attention check, or if participants fail to follow rules on the self-concept clarity manipulations.

q23.value: Missing data will be excluded in a pairwise fashion, only excluded from what they missed, but the rest of the data from that sample participant will be used.

attributes.title: Training volitional control of the theory of mind network with real-time fMRI neurofeedback

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Training volitional control of the theory of mind network with real-time fMRI neurofeedback in people with schizophrenia

other.value:
In addition to our primary hypotheses, we will conduct several secondary and exploratory analyses as follows:

•	We will evaluate whether the magnitude of the rt-fMRI NFB training effect is moderated by trait perspective-taking/empathy (as assessed with the Interpersonal Reactivity Index) and mental imagery ability (as assessed with the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire). 
•	We will perform qualitative and quantitative text-based analysis of self-reported regulation strategies and what participants report learning from the rt-fMRI training procedure to assess which regulation strategies (e.g., thinking about emotions versus other mental states) are associated with rt-fMRI training effects. 
•	We will evaluate participants’ subjective experience of the rt-fMRI training procedure (e.g., enjoyment, difficulty).

sample.value: 10 participants with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.

analyses.value: In order to evaluate hypothesis 1, we will conduct region-of-interest (ROI) analyses using individually-localized regions from the localizer tasks. ROI data will be entered into repeated-measures ANOVAs to test for the effect of session and condition (up-regulation, down-regulation), separately for training and transfer scans, and follow-up post-hoc one-sample tests. We will also conduct whole-brain analyses comparing up- versus down-regulation blocks, separately for training and transfer session. To evaluate hypothesis 2, we will evaluate pre- to post-rt-fMRI NFB performance on the behavioral measures, and evaluate the relation between changes in ROI activity and changes in behavioral performance.

outliers.value: If outlier ROI or behavioral data points (+/- 3 SD of the mean) are observed, data will be Winsorized.

dependent.value:
The primary dependent variable is neural activity from individually localized regions of the ToM-N during up- and down-regulation blocks. Before training begins, all participants will complete localizer scans to individually localize regions within the ToM-N. In the following training sessions, they will be asked to up- and down-regulate neural activity using feedback provided from these regions (i.e., training scans), and when no feedback is provided (i.e., transfer scans). The difference in neural activity between up- and down-regulation blocks will be used to assess the first hypothesis.

To address our second hypothesis, we will administer a battery of tasks before and after rt-fMRI NFB to assess whether the procedure is associated with changes in performance on a battery of tasks. These tasks will assess processes that are associated with neural response in regions of the ToM-N, and the temporo-parietal junction specifically, including social cognition, own-body imagery, and attentional reorienting:  This battery consists of the following measures:
•	Spontaneous Theory of Mind (STOMP) task
•	Mental State Fluency Task
•	Social Attribution Task (SAT-MC)
•	Hinting Task
•	Emotion Identification Task
•	Own-Body Transformation Task
•	Posner Cueing Task

conditions.value:
How many and which conditions will participants be assigned to?

This is a single-arm study that will evaluate within-group changes as a function of rt-fMRI NFB training.

hypothesis.value:
This study will test two main hypotheses related to real-time fMRI neurofeedback training (rt-fMRI NFB) within a healthy adult population.

Hypothesis 1: We predict that through rf-fMRI NFB training, participants will learn to self-regulate neural activity within the Theory of Mind Network (ToM-N), as evidenced by greater neural activity during up- versus down-regulation blocks in training sessions (i.e., with neurofeedback provided) and transfer sessions (i.e., with no neurofeedback provided). 

Hypothesis 2: Based on prior work demonstrating a connection between neural activity in the ToM-N and social cognitive ability outside of the scanner, we hypothesize that trained control of the ToM-N confers improvements in social ability as measured by a battery of social cognitive tests.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Training volitional control of the theory of mind network with real-time fMRI neurofeedback in people with schizophrenia
registration_responses.other:
In addition to our primary hypotheses, we will conduct several secondary and exploratory analyses as follows:

•	We will evaluate whether the magnitude of the rt-fMRI NFB training effect is moderated by trait perspective-taking/empathy (as assessed with the Interpersonal Reactivity Index) and mental imagery ability (as assessed with the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire). 
•	We will perform qualitative and quantitative text-based analysis of self-reported regulation strategies and what participants report learning from the rt-fMRI training procedure to assess which regulation strategies (e.g., thinking about emotions versus other mental states) are associated with rt-fMRI training effects. 
•	We will evaluate participants’ subjective experience of the rt-fMRI training procedure (e.g., enjoyment, difficulty).
registration_responses.sample: 10 participants with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
registration_responses.analyses: In order to evaluate hypothesis 1, we will conduct region-of-interest (ROI) analyses using individually-localized regions from the localizer tasks. ROI data will be entered into repeated-measures ANOVAs to test for the effect of session and condition (up-regulation, down-regulation), separately for training and transfer scans, and follow-up post-hoc one-sample tests. We will also conduct whole-brain analyses comparing up- versus down-regulation blocks, separately for training and transfer session. To evaluate hypothesis 2, we will evaluate pre- to post-rt-fMRI NFB performance on the behavioral measures, and evaluate the relation between changes in ROI activity and changes in behavioral performance.
registration_responses.outliers: If outlier ROI or behavioral data points (+/- 3 SD of the mean) are observed, data will be Winsorized.
registration_responses.dependent:
The primary dependent variable is neural activity from individually localized regions of the ToM-N during up- and down-regulation blocks. Before training begins, all participants will complete localizer scans to individually localize regions within the ToM-N. In the following training sessions, they will be asked to up- and down-regulate neural activity using feedback provided from these regions (i.e., training scans), and when no feedback is provided (i.e., transfer scans). The difference in neural activity between up- and down-regulation blocks will be used to assess the first hypothesis.

To address our second hypothesis, we will administer a battery of tasks before and after rt-fMRI NFB to assess whether the procedure is associated with changes in performance on a battery of tasks. These tasks will assess processes that are associated with neural response in regions of the ToM-N, and the temporo-parietal junction specifically, including social cognition, own-body imagery, and attentional reorienting:  This battery consists of the following measures:
•	Spontaneous Theory of Mind (STOMP) task
•	Mental State Fluency Task
•	Social Attribution Task (SAT-MC)
•	Hinting Task
•	Emotion Identification Task
•	Own-Body Transformation Task
•	Posner Cueing Task
registration_responses.conditions:
How many and which conditions will participants be assigned to?

This is a single-arm study that will evaluate within-group changes as a function of rt-fMRI NFB training.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This study will test two main hypotheses related to real-time fMRI neurofeedback training (rt-fMRI NFB) within a healthy adult population.

Hypothesis 1: We predict that through rf-fMRI NFB training, participants will learn to self-regulate neural activity within the Theory of Mind Network (ToM-N), as evidenced by greater neural activity during up- versus down-regulation blocks in training sessions (i.e., with neurofeedback provided) and transfer sessions (i.e., with no neurofeedback provided). 

Hypothesis 2: Based on prior work demonstrating a connection between neural activity in the ToM-N and social cognitive ability outside of the scanner, we hypothesize that trained control of the ToM-N confers improvements in social ability as measured by a battery of social cognitive tests.

Project Summary & Rationale

This project will survey North Carolina residents who may have their licenses suspended due to failure to pay fines or failure to appear in court. We want to survey why residents have not restored their driver’s license, and how having a suspended driver’s license has affected their life. Such information will give us a better understanding of how license suspension policies may put citizens into an inescapable cycle of being unable to pay fines, and result in indefinite suspensions for relatively minor legal infractions.

The project will also be comparing answers from those who live above the poverty line to those who live below the poverty line.

Sampling

We will recruit 800 North Carolina residents total.  400 participants will have incomes below the poverty line and four hundred participants will have incomes above the poverty line. Further, we plan to collect some participant identification information (names and birthdates) from 200 participants (100 above the poverty line, 100 below).

Participants recruited by Qualtrics will be emailed a link to the Qualtrics survey about participants’ experiences having a suspended driver’s license. Qualtrics recruits participants through volunteers who provide email addresses. 

200 participants will be asked to voluntarily provide their name for the research team to cross reference with a publicly available list of people with suspended licenses, to verify whether their licenses are actually suspended or not.  Evidence shows that people may have suspended licenses and not know it. The list of suspended drivers is available via a request from The Administrative of the Courts (AOC) and the Automated Criminal/Infractions System (ACIS).

We will also ask participants to provide their name and contact information if they would like to schedule a follow up interview.  Participants also have the option of being contacted if they are unaware of their license status and want to know if it is suspended.



Method / Procedure

The survey will collect information from participants on several measures.

1. First, we will collect anonymous demographic information from participants, including age, race, gender, family size, and income. 

2. Next, we will also ask participants about some factors of their day to day life, including employment history, how often they interact with law enforcement, how much they trust the criminal justice system, what their preferred form of communication with the justice system is (phone call, text, etc.), and whether their current address is up to date with the NC DMV. Importantly, we will also ask if their license is currently suspended.

3. Based on participant responses to whether their license is suspended, they will be directed to one of two blocks of questions.
	A. Participants who do have a suspended license will answer questions about their experiences having a suspended license, and how it has affected their day to day life. This includes questions on:
-Why the license was suspended?
-What year the license was suspended
-How the license has affected getting to work, keeping a job, feeling stressed, grocery shopping, accessing childcare, getting children to school, accessing leisure activities, pursuing education, spending times with friends, paying rent, going to the doctor, and getting medication.
-Life changes as the result of suspension, such as having to move and going off medications.
-Attempts to restore their license, or reasons for not doing so.
-Whether they still drive with a suspended license, why, and how often.

	B. Participants who do not have a suspended license will answer these questions in the hypothetical – “imagine if you had a license, how would it affect getting to work / keeping a job / etc.”
4. Participants will then be asked if they have anything else to add in a free response text, and then be directed to a second survey (to maintain anonymity) to provide PII if they choose.


Our complete survey is attached in QSF and .pdf form

Research Questions & Analysis Plan
This project is primarily exploratory and descriptive. We make no confirmatory hypotheses.

First and foremost, we are interested in learning more about how a driver’s license suspension affects the day to day life of participants. We are also interested in learning more about the process for participants that have suspended licenses, including what may have prevented them from restoring their license.

We are also interested in comparing participants above the poverty line to those below the poverty line, with the goal of determining if poor participants are more negatively impacted by a license suspension (or hypothetical suspension) than participants above the poverty line.

If we get enough (>75) participants in relevant conditions, we may also compare participants with actual suspensions to those without suspensions offering hypothetical ratings of the DVs, to see if participants can correctly imagine how a license suspension would impact them. 

Finally, we predict that at least 30% of participants who provide PII and report not having a suspended license will actually have a suspended license when cross-referenced by AOC data. We make this prediction based on an earlier project (forthcoming at UCLA Criminal Law Review: Modjadidi, Crozier & Garrett) that over 30% of a paper version of this survey was returned as undeliverable. Thus, we predict that 30% or more of suspended driver’s may not be receiving their notices of suspension and thus not know they are suspended. 


**Note**
We have soft-launched the study (50 participants) to ensure that Qualtrics can recruit like they promised. We have not analyzed the data, and confirmed that people were completing the survey, providing responses, we were able to collect PII, and that some of our respondents had driver's license suspensions (15/50).

q2.value: David Illingworth, Michael R Dougherty, Rick Thomas, Justin Sukernek

q3.value: Aggregating multiple estimates from the same individual has been shown to result in more accurate estimates—a phenomenon known as the wisdom of the crowd within (Vul & Pashler, 2008).  Accuracy improves when there is a time delay between estimates, suggesting that the passage of time interferes with one’s ability to remember and anchor on initial estimates.  This research has implications in domains where individuals must rely on their own, independent knowledge to forecast future events.  That is, rather than collaborate with or aggregate across estimates from multiple judges, an individual can simulate the benefits related to crowd wisdom by sampling repeatedly from their own knowledge.  However, the time delays necessary to achieve this advantage may not be realistic in domains with high time constraints.  The purpose of the current research project is to explore other methods for introducing interference between estimates.

q4.value: This study is comparing methods for eliciting multiple judgments for the same item from an individual. Our design includes methods that are meant to introduce interference (extra items, modular arithmetic task) in the memory system and some that do not (mere repeated judgments; dialectical bootstrapping). One specific, though broad, hypothesis is that aggregating multiple judgments when interference is introduced experimentally will result improved accuracy. We also predict that there will be less similarity between judgments when interference is introduced compared to when it is not.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
There will be 10 focal questions that will be repeated 5 times for each participant.  Five of these questions will be future forecast questions (e.g., How many copies of her record “Lover” will Taylor Swift sell in the month of May?). The other five questions will be general knowledge questions (e.g., What is the percentage of Asia’s land mass is accounted for in Turkey?).  There will be a distractor task that will be completed between each of the 5 repeated blocks of focal queries, which will vary by condition. Condition 1 will be a control condition, where there will be no intervening task.  In condition 2, participants will be asked to respond to a set distractor questions between each block of focal questions. In condition 3, participants will complete a mathematical evaluation task (Modular Arithmetic Task) which will require simple mental math (responses will regard whether or not a division problem has a remainder). In condition 4, we will implement a strategy referred to as Dialectical Bootstrapping, where participants will be presented with their previous judgment and consider reasons why it may be wrong before providing the next set of judgments.

All participants will receive $15 for each hour of participation.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization to assign participants to one of the four conditions described in the design section. The order in which the 10 focal questions are presented will also be randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Undergraduate students enrolled at the University of Maryland, College Park will be recruited to participate in this study via an online experiment management system (SONA Systems).  All individuals will receive $15 for their participation in the study. Incomplete data from a participant will be excluded from analysis.

q13.value: We are planning to run between 250 and 300 individuals in this experiment.

q14.value: We are anticipating a small to medium effect size and are aiming for 60 to 75 participants in each of four conditions.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data if we hit our maximum number of participants (300) or before the month of May begins, as the events participants will be forecasting take place in that month.

question.value: We are manipulating the source of interference across 4 levels. In the first condition, there are no additional tasks and each round of responses are identical to each other. In the second condition, there is no additional task; however, participants are prompted to engage in dialectical bootstrapping for each round of responding following the first round. In the third condition, participants have to respond to random distractor questions in-between rounds of responses to the focal questions. In the fourth condition, participants must complete a modular arithmetic task between rounds of responding to focal questions.

We are recording numeric responses to all questions focal or otherwise, We are also recording response times for all responses. In the modular arithmetic condition, we are recording the accuracy of their responses as well as RT.
We will average across each response participants give to a question. This aggregate response will be a mean of the 5 responses.
GLM analyses will be used to determine what if any differences can be detected across the four conditions as it relates to accuracy in judgment or the correlation across their judgments.

q21.value: Bayes factors will be used to draw inferences, and will not consider a cutoff but the continuum.

q22.value: Data from any participant who did not complete the study will be excluded.

q23.value: Missing data will result in excluding that participant from analysis.

In condition 4, we will implement a strategy referred to as Dialectical Bootstrapping, where participants will be presented with their previous judgment and consider reasons why it may be wrong before providing the next set of judgments.

All participants will receive $15 for each hour of participation.
registration_responses.q12.question: Undergraduate students enrolled at the University of Maryland, College Park will be recruited to participate in this study via an online experiment management system (SONA Systems).  All individuals will receive $15 for their participation in the study. Incomplete data from a participant will be excluded from analysis.
registration_responses.q16.question: We are manipulating the source of interference across 4 levels. In the first condition, there are no additional tasks and each round of responses are identical to each other. In the second condition, there is no additional task; however, participants are prompted to engage in dialectical bootstrapping for each round of responding following the first round. In the third condition, participants have to respond to random distractor questions in-between rounds of responses to the focal questions. In the fourth condition, participants must complete a modular arithmetic task between rounds of responding to focal questions.
registration_responses.q17.question: We are recording numeric responses to all questions focal or otherwise, We are also recording response times for all responses. In the modular arithmetic condition, we are recording the accuracy of their responses as well as RT.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will average across each response participants give to a question. This aggregate response will be a mean of the 5 responses.
registration_responses.q19.question: GLM analyses will be used to determine what if any differences can be detected across the four conditions as it relates to accuracy in judgment or the correlation across their judgments.

attributes.title: Experiences of family members of those charged with a cyber-enabled sexual offence: an interpretative phenomenological analysis in collaboration with Stop it Now! Scotland

q1.value: Experiences of family members of those charged with a cyber-enabled sexual offence: an interpretative phenomenological analysis in collaboration with Stop it Now! Scotland

q2.value: Miriam Cohen, Alana Davis, Ethel Quayle

q3.value: This study aims to investigate the lived experience of family members of those charged with a cyber-enabled sexual offence, specifically possession of indecent images of children (IIOC). This study will utilise a qualitative research design, using interpretative phenomenological analysis to identify themes within the data. We aim to recruit 15 individuals, partners, parents and adult siblings of those accused to better understand how people cope and make sense of these experiences. This study is in collaboration with the Lucy Faithful Foundation's Stop it Now! Organisation.

q4.value: There are no directional hypotheses for this study, but the research aims to provide a better understanding of the lived experiences of family members of those accused of possession of IIOC, and the sense they make of these experiences. This will inform how best to provide support and improve outcomes for the accused and their families.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Qualitative research design, using semi-structured interviews

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will work in collaboration with the SIN-S organisation, which is a national child protection charity, run by the Lucy Faithful Foundation as a campaign for child sexual abuse prevention. The charity provides information, increases public awareness, offers training for people working with children and families, runs an anonymous and confidential helpline and facilitates online and face-to-face intervention programmes. It targets people who are worried about their own or another’s behaviour, friends and relatives of people arrested for sexual offending and survivors or professional working with child abuse. This study is conducted in collaboration with SIN-S staff who specialise in working with the families of those accused.
We will recruit romantic partners, parents or siblings of people charged with a possession of IIOC and we will aim to sample approximately five people in each group, with a total group size of 15. The SIN-S collaborator will identify current and previous clients suitable for participation in the study. SIN-S staff will make initial contact with study details. If individuals are interested in participating, further information will be provided in the form of an information sheet including the researcher’s contact details for further discussion over phone, email, or in person. If they decide to take part in the study or wish to meet in person to discuss the study in more detail, an appointment will be booked through SIN-S to meet at the base in Edinburgh. This is the most effective logistical plan as room availability at the SIN-S base is limited and the interviews will need to be scheduled in accordance with this. If it is not possible for the participant to arrange travel to Edinburgh, then the option of a home visit will be discussed in accordance with the lone working protocol.

Inclusion criteria include:
 The participants must either be a parent, sibling or romantic partner of, an individual who is currently being charged with an internet-based sexual offence (possession of IIOC), affiliated with the SIN-S charity.
 They need to reside in Scotland. This will aid recruitment feasibility and homogeneity of the recruited sample.
Exclusion criteria include:
 Participants affiliated with individuals with a current charge of a grooming internet-based sexual offence, a contact offence or creation and distribution of IIOC (rather than possession only). This is based on the rationale that the experiences of partners and families charged with these offences may have a different experience and different interpretation of these events and it is important in IPA to aim to keep the sample as homogenous as possible. I specify ‘current charge’ here as it is difficult to determine whether there are any undisclosed previous offences that the researcher and the family members may be unaware of. Possession of IIOC is the most common charge referred to SIN-S which aids recruitment feasibility for this population.
 Parents or partners of individuals charged with possession of IIOC, not affiliated with the charity SIN-S. Affiliation with the organisation helps the research team ensure that the individuals meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria and help ensure there are no additional risks in terms of safety and emotional distress that may arise during the interview process.
 Children or friends of those accused.
 Those in the acute or ‘crisis stage’ of the punitive process. Involvement in the study after the ‘safety and stabilisation’ phase of their work with SIN-S will be more appropriate and likely less distressing for the participants. There is no specified time period for this, it will be determined on a case-by-case process by SIN-S staff.
 Individuals who do not speak English fluently
 Individuals who are under 18 years of age

q13.value: N = 15 (n = 5 parents, n = 5 partners, n = 5 siblings)

q14.value:
We will aim to recruit 15 participants. For IPA each subjective account is analysed in detail and the intensity of this activity requires relatively small sample sizes (Smith, 2011). Through discussion with skilled IPA analysts, it was agreed that n = 5 per group would be an appropriate sample size. If there are difficulties recruiting that number for a particular group due to lower representation of those family members in the service (i.e. siblings), we will aim to supplement these numbers with additional parent or partner participants.

Confidence in being able to recruit a sample of this size derives from the large number of people contacting SIN-S who meet the eligibility criteria for this study (with 86 referrals of family members in the previous year). These individuals have been receptive previously when asked to provide written statements or narratives of their experiences, therefore it seems logical that they or others would be interested in participating in qualitative interviews (although we acknowledge that for some providing written accounts may be less distressing). There is a given impression from feasibility meetings with SIN-S that this is a marginalised population that are not often heard. Inclusion in a study such as this, with the intention of informing others, would likely be beneficial and meaningful for those involved. In addition to this, SIN-S have collaborated previously with the University of Edinburgh on other projects where the sample size has exceeded the initial estimations, due to interest in the study and the efforts of the SIN collaborators in facilitating the recruitment process.

question.value: Not applicable
Not applicable
Not applicable - qualitative analysis

attributes.title: Self-serving Bias, Forecasting Skills (Overconfidence), and Misattribution of Fail/Success in Czech Uni Applicants

q1.value: Self-serving Bias, Forecasting Skills (Overconfidence), and Misattribution of Fail/Success in Czech Uni Applicants

q2.value: Nikola Frollova, Marcel Tkáčik, Petr Houdek

q3.value:
The data sample is Czech university applicants participating in general study aptitude test. This sample is complemented by a minority of students who after the general test continue to participate in basic humanities and social science knowledge test. First, we will ask every applicant for the prediction of the score they will most likely achieve in the test. This question has four versions: 1) Precise percentile; 2) Range of percentiles; 3) Precise percentile and then Range of percentiles; 4) Range of percentiles and then Precise percentile.
Using a questionnaire we will measure how much participants believe that their result will be determined by their effort (variable to measure internal attribution, intAtt), how much they believe that their result will be influenced by luck or bad luck for test questions (variable to measure external attribution, extAtt) )and how much the participants believe that their relatives and friends would be disappointed if they will not achieve their desired results (proxy variable for social pressure, socPress). In addition, the part of the students that continues to the subsequent test will be given the same questionnaire, with questions formulated in the past tense to measure the effect of experience on predictions and attribution of perceived failure or success.

q4.value:
H1: We predict the type of prediction question will affect the prediction precision.
H2: We predict perceived social pressure will be associated with a perceived higher possibility of influences of factors other than participant's effort.
H3: Estimation accuracy will be associated with types of attribution (internal/external) 
Hypotheses concerning participants who complete before and after questionnaire:
H4: We predict that applicants who perceive social pressure will more likely attribute perceived failure to external factors 
H5: If the prediction before and after differ, we expect differences in attribution as well.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

We will investigate two phenomenons - self-serving bias and overconfidence/ forecasting skills.
The data sample is Czech university applicants participating in general study aptitude test. First, we will ask every applicant for the prediction of the score they will most likely achieve in the test. q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Scio.cz company will provide data collection services as they are also the administrators of the entire testing.

q13.value: The estimated number of participants is around 3000

question.value:
We manipulate by the type of prediction question:
1) Precise percentile
2) Range of percentiles
3) Precise percentile and then Range of percentiles
4) Range of percentiles and then Precise percentile.

First, we will ask every applicant for the prediction of the score they will most likely achieve in the test. This question has four versions: 1) Precise percentile; 2) Range of percentiles; 3) Precise percentile and then Range of percentiles; 4) Range of percentiles and then Precise percentile.
Using a questionnaire we will measure how much participants believe that their result will be determined by their effort (variable to measure internal attribution, intAtt), how much they believe that their result will be influenced by luck or bad luck for test questions (variable to measure external attribution, extAtt) )and how much the participants believe that their relatives and friends would be disappointed if they will not achieve their desired results (proxy variable for social pressure, socPress). In addition, the part of the students that continues to the subsequent test will be given the same questionnaire, with questions formulated in the past tense to measure the effect of experience on predictions and attribution of perceived failure or success. SCIO company provides us the real scores that the participants achieved.

Type of estimation question: categorical variable questEst with 4 categories for each variation
Measures of score prediction precision:  root mean square error of score prediction (RMSE) to measure absolute error, estimation range measure as a difference between top and bottom point of the interval. Point estimation of range computed as a mean of top and bottom of the range. Absolute personal difference of estimation (diffEst) versus real score is simply a subtraction of two scores * -1 and is complemented by the dummy  (dDirection) to note a direction (overestimation =1, underestimation or perfect match is noted by 0).
Personal controls: a standard set of personal controls is provided by the SCIO company plus the information about how many times the unique participant attended the test during the testing year

Indep. Vars: socPress, diffEst
Dep. vars: intAtt, extAtt

H1: We predict the type of prediction question will affect the prediction precision.
ANOVA, lin.reg. model with 4 categories of questEst as dummies

H2: We predict perceived social pressure will be associated with a perceived higher possibility of influences of factors other than participant's effort.

Linear regression models to check for the effect of socPress on attributions:

intAtt = Bo + B1 * socPress + persControl + u
extAtt = Bo + B1 * socPress + persControl + u

Plus local regression models to check for the effect of socPress on attributions using the z-scores of variables (regression designs are the same just the comput. method changes and variables are transformed to z-scores)

q1.value: Examining frequency effects for verbs belonging to the strong conjugation class in German with a lexical decision task

q3.value:
This is a replication of the preregistration for the pre-study  made on 14th November 2019 which has been withdrawn accidentally. The mistake was noticed on 13th Februrary 2020. The preregistration is only replicated in order to help readers understand the references  to the withdrawn preregistration in the preregistration for the main study made on 8th January 2020.  The original preregistration has been made before collection of data, of course this is not the case for this registration.

Frequency is a well-studied factor influencing variation (Bybee 1985, 2006, 2013, Nowak 2015). Type frequency influences variation in general: Inflection classes with low type frequency lose their members to type frequent classes. Type frequency also interacts with regularity. Mostly, classes with high type frequency show a regular conjugation pattern whereas classes with low type frequency show an irregular conjugation pattern (Goldberg 2019: 66-68).

Within the classes with low type frequency, token frequency influences whether a member will stay in the class or change to the type frequent class: token frequent members stay in the type infrequent class, while token infrequent members change to the type frequent class (Bybee and Thompson 1997). This principle has been studied in several corpus studies (e.g., Nowak 2015, Schäfer 2016). However, psycholinguistic studies on frequency and variation do not exist. 

In the past, psycholinguistic studies focussed on the difference between the processing of regular and irregular morphology and on the question whether token frequency only influences the processing of irregular conjugation, but not of regular conjugation (dual mechanism model by Pinker and Prince 1991; see Bornkessel-Schlesewsky 2009: 47-68 for an overview over the studies). Token frequency influences reaction times with regard to irregular verbs in general: Clahsen et al. (2001) report that preterite forms of irregular German verbs with a low frequency of preterite forms elicit slower reaction times in a lexical decision task than preterite forms of verbs with a high frequency of preterite forms. 
However, it has not been studied so far whether variation caused by low frequency might affect reaction times. It would be interesting to test whether the results of Clahsen et al. (2001) also hold for regular forms of irregular verbs with differing token frequencies. Additionally, it has not been examined whether variation can be detected in reaction times before it is visible in corpora. Here, irregular verbs are of interest that do not vary in corpora yet but have similar token frequencies as verbs that already show variation. Again, not only the reaction times elicited by irregular forms but also by regular forms of the verbs are of interest.

This study aims to answer the research questions with the help of a lexical decision task. For the task, verbs are used that belong to the type infrequent irregular (strong) conjugation class in German. The verbs have differing participle frequencies and show different degrees of variation in corpora. Participants are asked to judge the participle forms of the test verbs which are presented with strong (irregular) as well as weak (regular) inflection.

q4.value:
frequent vs. infrequent

The reaction times depend on the frequency of the test verbs: Reaction times are lower for frequent strong verbs (over 13 hits per million tokens), whereas reaction times are higher for infrequent strong verbs (up to 2 hits per million tokens). This can be observed for weak as well as strong forms and for the acceptance as well as the rejection of forms. The relative frequency of the test verbs is determined with the help of the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften).

With the help of the design, reaction times can be interpreted as an indicator for variation. From a frequency-based view, reaction times should be shorter for frequent verbs than for infrequent verbs (Clahsen et al. 2001). The design allows to control for the general influence of frequency: Weak forms of token frequent verbs (e.g., "gezieht" instead of "gezogen" 'pulled') occur extremly seldom in language use and are thus not token frequent. A fast rejection of these forms can therefore not be traced back to the frequency of the forms. The same logic holds for weak forms of infrequent verbs ("gefechtet" instead of "gefochten" 'fenced') that are not attested in corpora yet (ratio of more than 100 strong forms to one weak form).  
Differences in reaction times can thus be interpreted as an indicator for variants:  entrenched forms are accepted fast and forms that are unlikely to be produced are rejected fast whereas the judgement of variants takes longer because two forms with equal function exist. Hence, the form "gezieht" should be rejected fast, but not "geflechtet": "geflechtet" is not attested in corpora yet, but the strong participle of "flechten" is similar frequent as the participles of other verbs that already show variation (e.g., "salzen" 'to salt'). Crucially, the hypothesised difference in reaction times cannot be traced back to differences in token frequency between the verb forms, as the token frequency of both forms ("geflechtet" and "gezieht") is equally low because both forms are nearly inexistent. 

attested vs. not attested

The infrequent verbs are divided into the categories variation attested in corpora and variation not attested in corpora. Based on a usage-based framework, it is hypothesised that no difference can be measured in the reaction times between forms that are attested in corpora and forms that are not attested in corpora. This holds for strong and weak forms as well as the acceptance and the rejection of forms. As the verbs are infrequent, the strong forms of the verbs are infrequent as well and thus cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency. Hence, the statistical pre-emption (Goldberg 2019: 75-84) of strong forms is impaired. Strong and weak forms can be considered variants for infrequent strong verbs. Reaction times are therefore higher as two forms with equal function exists. 

Note that it is also possible to expect differences in reaction time within a usage-based framework. As the weak forms are more seldom for verbs without attested variation and strong forms are in turn more frequent, a slight difference in reaction times might be observable between verbs with attested and verbs without attested variation. If weak forms occur only seldom, these forms should be rejected fast and the correspondent strong form should be accepted fast, as this is the only entrenched form. In contrast, longer reaction times are expected if weak forms occur more often as now there are two competing forms. However, this difference should be more subtle than the difference between frequent and infrequent test verbs because the strong forms of infrequent verbs cannot dominate the weak forms in frequency as much as strong forms of frequent verbs can.  
The design allows testing both hypotheses. The test verbs are selected by calculating the ratio of strong and weak participle forms using the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). The search was carried out with Cosmas 2 (Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). A form is defined to be attested in corpora if the ratio of strong to weak forms is smaller than 100/1. If no differences in reaction times can be measured between verbs with and without attested variation, this can be taken as an indicator that variation is already measurable before it is attested in corpora. 

2. acceptability and consistency of answers

frequent vs. infrequent

The acceptability of weak and strong forms depends on the token frequency of strong verbs. Strong forms are accepted for frequent strong verbs, whereas weak forms are not accepted. For infrequent strong verbs, both forms are accepted. 
For frequent verbs, a clearly distributed response behaviour is expected: predominantly rejection for weak forms and predominantly acceptance for strong forms. This is not expected for infrequent verbs: while acceptance is expected for strong forms, a mixed response behaviour is expected for weak forms. Additionally, the response behaviour of individual participants is expected to be consistent for frequent verbs (rejection of the weak form of a verb, acceptance of the strong form) but not for infrequent verbs (rejection/acceptance of both forms). 

variation attested in corpora vs. not attested in corpora

For infrequent test verbs, it is hypothesized that the acceptability of weak forms is influenced by the occurrence of weak forms in corpora. Although a corpus cannot picture language use as a whole, it can nonetheless give a hint on how likely it is that a certain form has been produced by speakers and hence perceived by other speakers. If weak forms are already attested in corpora, it is more likely that participants already encountered these forms and that the forms are more entrenchend. The opposite is to be expected for forms that are not attested in corpora. Weak forms are therefore more likely to be accepted if they already have been witnessed in corpora.  

Note that this hypothesis is not the only possible hypothesis from a usage-based perspective. Comparable acceptance rates can also be expected: As the frequency of the strong participles is low for verbs with attested as well as without attested variation, the verbs could be treated in the same way. Hence, it is also possible that the infrequent verbs with and without attested variation show comparable acceptance and rejection rates of the weak and strong participle forms. The study design allows testing both hypotheses.

question.value:
A within subject design is used with two factors (frequency and inflection), that have three (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of frequency, eight test words are used.  The participants are shown test words with weak as well as strong inflection and are asked to decide whether they know the word ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/word sequence?'). The answer (yes/no) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
So called weak masculine nouns with weak and strong inflection are used as fillers. They serve as test nouns for a study on the influence of schematicity on variation. Additionally,  strong genitive forms ending with -es are used as fillers. The genitive form -es is used for nouns that normally have -s as genitive ending as they do not allow -es phonotactically (*des Abendes 'the evening.GEN') (Szczepaniak 2010). 
To test the design, reaction times elicited by long (-es) and short (-s) genitive endings of two nouns not allowing long genitive endings are contrasted (Ultimatum, Internet) as well as reaction times elicited by regular and irregular forms of the irregular verbs "gehen" 'to go' and "bringen" 'to bring'. These items will only be relevant if the statistical analysis of the test items does not hint to differences in reaction times.  The items allow to test whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The following mixed linear model will be used  if the design needs to be tested: reaction time ~ acceptance + (1+acceptance|item)+(1+acceptance|participant). Acceptance is the manipulated variable. The variabel has two levels: accepted (short ending/irregular form) and not accepted (long ending/regular form). Additionally, the response behaviour (yes/no) of the participants will be analysed with the following logistic mixed linear model (acceptance ~ form + (1+form|item)+(1+form|participant). Form is the manipulated variable. The variable has two levels (long ending/regular form vs. short ending/irregular form). 

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study.

Test items

See the attached file (testverbs.csv) for an overview over the test verbs. The selection of the test verbs is based on the relative frequency of the test verbs' strong participles in the year 2018. The relative frequencies of the participles are taken from the word frequencies provided by the digital dictionary of the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test verbs with a participle frequency of 13 and more hits per million token are considered frequent. Test verbs with a participle frequency of up to 2 hits per million token are considered infrequent. 

Within the infrequent test verbs, verbs with a ratio of more than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered not to vary in corpora, test verbs with a ratio of less than 100 strong participle forms to one weak form are considered to vary in corpora. The counts for the strong and weak participle forms are based on the corpus w-public of the archive W for written language (W-öffentlich - alle öffentlichen Korpora des Archivs W) which is part of the German Reference Corpus (Deutsches Referenzkorpus, Leibniz-Institut für Deutsche Sprache). Only the hits for the weak forms of the frequent test verbs have been searched for false positives. Note that only hits with lower case for "gefahren" ('driven')  were included into the search in order to avoid false positives as "gefahren" in upper case is homographic to the dative plural of "Gefahr" ‘danger’.   

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over all test items as well as fillers. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: unique coding for each stimulus 	
Stimulus: the stimulus as presented to the participant	
Schema: coding for the masculine test nouns; levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach (not relevant for this study)
Frequenz: coding for the test verbs; levels: frequent, infrequ_m, infrequ_o
Akzeptanz: coding for the items testing the design; levels: nichtakzeptiert, akzeptiert	
Evaluation: "ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 20 % of the items have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	
Flexion: coding for the test verbs and nouns; levels: stark/schwach	
Item: naming the test items in their base form (test verbs as well as masculine test nouns that are not relevant for this study)
Formakzeptiert: (expected) acceptence/inacceptance of the forms, j (yes), n (no), b (both)
correctKey: correct response key (based on Formakzeptiert); levels: f (no), j (yes, both)
Block: block in which the item is presented	
PositionimBlock: position within the block

Further explanation for the columns "Formakzeptiert" and "correctKey": Concerning the test verbs, the coding followed the hypotheses: for frequent verbs, weak forms are coded as rejected and strong forms as accepted. For infrequent verbs without attested variation (infrequ_o), the same coding scheme was used. For infrequent verbs with attested variation (infrequ_m), both forms were coded as accepted.

q9.value: The test items are organized in four blocks. Each block consists of 25 items. In the blocks, twelve test items (four test items per level) are included. Weak and strong forms of a single test verb are not used within one block but spread across blocks. Within the blocks, the order of the test verbs does not vary. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

question.value:
For a pre-study, participants will be recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. In the main study, participants will be additionally recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task. This evaluation will be based on 31 items. For these items, people should not vary in their answers (the 31 items are fillers as well as words used in the example block and words that are used to evaluate the design of the study). The cut-off point is set to 20 %. Hence, participants that answer seven items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. 

If the design has to be tested (see study design for further explanations), only the filler items as well as the items from the example block will be used to evaluate the participants' reponse behaviour. These are 23 items. Hence, the cut-off point will be set to 5 or more items that have been answered in the opposite way in this case.

The study will be carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/decision.

q13.value: In the pre-study, a sample size of 25 participants is targeted. In case that participants have to be excluded, data from 30 participants will be collected. On the basis of the pre-study, the sample size for the main study will be calculated.

q14.value: For the main study, an alpha-level of .05 and a power of .8 is targeted. The sample size will be calculated using the estimates of the pre-study. The estimates of the pre-study (most importantly the differences in the reaction times between the levels of frequency) will be based on a mixed linear model using the data of the pre-study (see statistical models). To calculate the required sample size, a power analysis based on the estimates provided by the pre-study will be conducted. As it is expected that the difference in reaction times will be more subtle than the differences in the acceptability rates, the power analysis will only be calculated for the reaction times.

question.value: Frequency was manipulated by choosing test verbs with differing participle frequencies. The three levels of this categorical variable are frequent, infrequent without variation and infrequent with variation (see study design for a definition of the levels). Additionally, the forms of the test words were manipulated. The levels of this nominal variable are weak and strong.

The outcome variables are response behaviour (yes/no) as well as reaction times to weak and strong participle forms of strong verbs with varying token frequencies (see manipulated variables). The response behaviour is measured by asking the participants 'Do you know this word/word sequence?' ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?"). Participants can only choose between yes and no. Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 


Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data will be used to exclude participants (see data collection procedures) but will not be used for the confirmatory analysis of the study.

For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019; RStudio team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction Times
To calculate the differences in reaction times, a mixed linear model is used. The frequency class of the verbs (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) and the forms (strong, weak) will be included as fixed effects.  The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ frequency class + form + (1+frequency|item) + (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model. 

Acceptance
To evaluate the differences in acceptance (yes/no), a logistic mixed linear model is used. Forms (strong, weak) as well as frequency class (frequent, infrequent without variation, infrequent with variation) are included as fixed effects that may interact (rejection of weak inflection for a frequent verb but not for an infrequent verb). Item and participant are included as random effects.  The independent variables are the frequency class and the forms. Acceptance is the dependent variable.

acceptance ~ frequency class * form + (1+frequency|item)+ (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

Consistency

No-answers will be re-coded for the weak forms to be yes-answers. In this way, the consistency of answers can be evaluated: If strong and weak forms of a noun are judged differently, the re-coding of the weak forms should lead to consistent answers per noun. To test this, a logistic mixed linear model is used. Frequency is included as fixed effect. Item and participant are included as random effects. The independent variable is frequency. Consistency is the dependent variable.

consistency ~ frequeny + (1+frequency|item)+ (1+frequency|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

q20.value:
If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.

Inference criteria

q21.value: The alpha-level is set to .05. The effect size will be estimated based on the pre-study.

q22.value: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants’ response behaviour will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation.

q23.value: Incomplete data sets of participants will not be included into the study.
